doc.after: Frank James Cooper was born on May 7, 1901, at 730 Eleventh Avenue in Helena, Montana[1][Note 1] to English immigrants Alice (nÃ©e Brazier, 1873â1967)[4] and Charles Henry Cooper (1865â1946).[5] His father emigrated to Montana from Houghton Regis, Bedfordshire[6] and became a prominent lawyer, rancher, and eventually a Montana Supreme Court justice.[7] His mother emigrated from Gillingham, Kent and married Charles in Montana.[8] In 1906, Charles purchased the 600-acre (240Â ha) Seven-Bar-Nine[9][10] cattle ranch about fifty miles (eighty kilometers) north of Helena near the town of Craig on the Missouri River.[11] Frank and his older brother Arthur spent their summers there and learned to ride horses, hunt, and fish.[12][13] In April 1908, the Hauser Dam failed and flooded the Missouri River valley along portions of the Cooper property, but Cooper and his family were able to evacuate in time.[14] Cooper attended Central Grade School in Helena.[2]
